name: Robin Kelly
tweet_text:
So what I am asking is that today, as you reflect on where you were on 9/11, you remember the unity felt in the days and weeks after that terrible day. 

As you go into next week, be kind to your fellow Americans. Be helpful. Honor those we lost 20 years ago today with unity.

name: Robin Kelly
tweet_text: It saddens me that we are a nation so divided now. We must embody the spirit of kindness and helpfulness without going through another tragedy to pull us together.

name: Robin Kelly
tweet_text: But more than the heartbreak & sadness, I was moved by the unity and kindness people displayed for one another. Strangers helping strangers. All of America rooting for New York & DC & Pennsylvania.

name: Robin Kelly
tweet_text: I knew it would be a difficult scene, but nothing can prepare you for that kind of carnage, the smoke rising from the wreckage or witnessing the despair of families still searching and hoping to find their loved ones.

name: Robin Kelly
tweet_text:
Like everyone else, I was terrified & heartbroken by this tragedy. I grieved for the people who never came home from work at the towers & the Pentagon, or their flight. 

I went to New York as soon as we could. I needed to see it for myself. I needed to see my friends & family.

name: Robin Kelly
tweet_text:
Whenever big, lifechanging events happen, we remember where we were or what we were doing that day. 

Illinois is my home now, but I'm a native New Yorker. My family & best friends still live there. They're the people I was thinking of when I heard the terrible news 20 years ago.

name: Robin Kelly
tweet_text:
It was an honor to attend and speak at a 9/11 Memorial Ceremony this morning in Park Forest.

As we reflect on the 20 year anniversary of this terrible attack on our country and the lives lost, I want to encourage you to do something. üßµ https://t.co/H5NieVEEAB
